definition: I have much more to say than can be written in this letter (conventional letter ending) (idiom)
abbr. for 書經|书经[Shu1 jing1]
book/letter/document/CL:本[ben3],冊|册[ce4],部[bu4]/to write
(negative prefix)/not/no
to use up/to exhaust/to end/to finish/to the utmost/exhausted/finished/to the limit (of sth)/all/entirely
to the greatest extent/(when used before a noun of location) furthest or extreme/to be within the limits of/to give priority to
words/speech/to say/to talk
(conventional letter ending) words cannot fully express what is in my heart (idiom)
saying everything/to speak out fully
to explain in simple terms/succinct/concise
to mention some but omit many others (idiom)/to leave out much more than one includes
to write elegantly
classical final particle, similar to modern 了[le5]
to write freely/to express oneself as one pleases

lit. Ying writes a letter and Yan reads it/fig. to misinterpret the original meaning/to pile up errors/refers to the letter from capital 郢[Ying3] of 楚[Chu3] in which the inadvertent words "hold up the candle" are mistaken by the minister of 燕[Yan1] as "promote the wise"
simple words with a profound meaning (idiom)
a thousand tries leads to one success (idiom, humble expr.); Even without any notable ability on my part, I may still get it right sometimes by good luck.
every word a gem (idiom); magnificent writing
in my humble opinion (idiom)
phrase
inexpressible (idiom)/beyond description
one's words reflect one's thinking (idiom)
